Synthesis of middle distillate through low temperature Fischer-Tropsch (LTFT) reaction over mesoporous SDA supported cobalt catalysts using syngas equivalent to coal gasification Sandip Mandal a ⁎ Sudip Maity a ⁎ Pavan K. Gupta a Abhishek Mahato a Piyali Bhanja b Gajanan Sahu a a Gasification and Liquefaction Research Group, CSIR-Central Institute of Mining and Fuel Research (DC), Dhanbad, 828108, India Gasification and Liquefaction Research Group CSIR-Central Institute of Mining and Fuel Research (DC) Dhanbad 828108 India b Department of Material Science, Indian Association for Cultivation of Science, Jadavpur, Kolkata, 700032, India Department of Material Science Indian Association for Cultivation of Science Jadavpur Kolkata 700032 India ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A series of silica doped alumina (SDA) [Si-Al2O3] having high surface area and narrow pore size distribution are synthesized with varying amount of silica and used as a support material to facilitate incorporation of Co, Mg and Zr into it. These supported Co-Mg-Zr/SDA materials are used as catalysts for selective synthesis of middle distillate through Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) reaction. Trace quantity (∼0.05 wt %) of ruthenium (Ru) has also been used as a promoter for Co -Mg-Zr/SDA catalyst to improve the reducibility, selectivity towards middle distillate and increasing the catalyst life. The detail characterizations of catalysts indicate that Ru promotion and narrow pore size distribution facilitate CO conversion and middle distillate selectivity. Synthetic syngas of composition (H2 = 28.63%, CO = 14.27%, CO2 = 9.25%, CH4 = 1.0%, and N2 = 46.85%), which may be obtained after coal gasification and H2 enrichment process by water gas shift (WGS) reaction has been used as a reactant for middle distillate synthesis. The role of Ru and silica proportion on Co-Mg-Zr/SDA is investigated through Low Temperature Fischer-Tropsch (LTFT) synthesis at 220 °C temperature and 30 bar pressure. The surface acidity of the Ru/Co-Mg-Zr/SDA catalyst plays an important role for middle distillate selectivity and CO conversion. To determine the durability of catalysts, 300 h continuous experimental run has been conducted at Gas Hourly Space Velocity (GHSV) of 500 h−1. Among the catalysts in the present study, Ru/Co-Mg-Zr/SDA(7.5) catalyst shows highest CO conversion (94.2%) with 85% selectivity of C6-C19 hydrocarbon. Keywords Catalysis Syngas Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Doped alumina Middle distillate 1 Introduction Middle distillate synthesis by using carbonaceous feed stocks such as coal, natural gas, biomass, is one of the most widely investigated research fields in last several decades. The limited reserve of petroleum crude and its geographical distributions force to find out an alternative way for its synthesis by using carbonaceous feedstocks. Coal gasification for syngas (CO + H2) production and its liquefaction to liquid hydrocarbon [(CH2)n ] via FTS process can somewhat achieve the target and also increase the strategic value of coal. Utilization of CO2 enriched syngas produced from coal gasification to liquid hydrocarbon synthesis is an important aspect in the development of Coal – to – Liquid (CTL) technology. For this purpose, synthesis of active and durable catalyst is another challenge in CTL process. Iron and cobalt are the two metals used as active components for FTS process [1–6]. Design and synthesis of Co based FT catalyst, which can give liquid hydrocarbon products through Low Temperature Fischer-Tropsch (LTFT) synthesis is a scientific challenge for last few decades. Highly dispersed metal catalyst with improved thermal, mechanical and chemical stability can address these issues. It is widely investigated that alumina, silica, titania and carbon based materials are effectively used as a support material for synthesis of cobalt based catalyst [7–12]. Mesoporous composite metal oxide with high surface area and uniform pore size distribution is successfully used as an efficient support for cobalt based catalyst. The mesoporosity of support material maximizes the dispersion of active metal as well as thermal, mechanical and chemical stability of Fischer-Tropsch (FT) catalyst. Beside this, mesoporous structure of catalyst provides maximum contact between active metal nanoclustures and reactant gas molecules. These kind of composite metal oxides facilitate CO conversion and desired product selectivity by regulating the acidity and structural stability of the catalyst. For cobalt based catalysts, interaction between cobalt particles and support material determines the cobalt dispersion and degree of reduction of cobalt species [13,14]. The smaller particle size of cobalt makes strong interaction with support material which decreases reducibility of the cobalt oxide species however addition of trace quantity of noble metal (e.g. Ru, Pt, Pd etc.) promotes reduction [15,16]. A series of paraffins, olefins and lower hydrocarbons are obtained from FT reaction but selective production of middle distillates is the major target and this can be achieved by proper design of catalyst. The low temperature reaction and using equivalent feed gas composition obtained after gasification of available carbonaceous feedstock like coal, biomass is an important perspective of industrial application of FT synthesis. The selective production of middle distillates can be achieved by optimization of reaction temperature [17,18], pressure, surface area, pore diameter [19,20], acidity [19,21] and noble metal (Ru, Pt, Pd, Re) promotion on the catalyst surface [22–27]. The transition metal oxides like manganese oxide, zirconium oxide, zinc oxide and titanium oxide also influence the selective production of middle distillate for cobalt based catalyst [23–29]. The Ru and Mg promotes the long term activity of catalyst during FT synthesis by minimizing the carbon deposition on catalyst surface [30,31]. In this study, mesoporous SDA is taken as a support material for development of cobalt based catalyst. In order to increase the mechanical and chemical stability, certain amount of magnesium and zirconium are incorporated on SDA by wet impregnation method. Further to increase CO conversion and catalyst stability during prolong on-stream reaction, trace quantity (0.05 wt%) of Ru has been deposited on Co-Mg-Zr/SDA by deposition-precipitation method. The catalysts are thoroughly characterized by different techniques e.g. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm, X-ray diffraction, high resolution transmission electron microscopy along with elemental mapping, H2-Temperature Programmed Reduction and NH3-Temperature Programmed Desorption. The catalyst Ru/Co-Mg-Zr/SDA is taken in a fixed bed reactor and reaction is carried out for 300 h at 220 °C temperature and 30 bar pressure by using equivalent gas composition obtained after air blown gasification of coal and H2 enrichment process (H2 = 28.63%, CO = 14.27%, CO2 = 9.25%, CH4 = 1.0% and N2 = 46.85%). In the present study, the catalyst: Ru/Co-Mg-Zr/SDA(7.5) shows 94.2% CO and 62.8% H2 conversion and 85% C6-C19 selectivity. This catalyst may successfully be used for industrial application of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis i.e. carbonaceous feed stokes to liquid hydrocarbon synthesis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All chemicals and reagents used are obtained from commercial source and are used without further purification; Pluronic (P123, MW–5800) [99%, Sigma-Aldrich], 35% Hydrochloric acid (HCl) [Merck India], Tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS) [>98%, Merck Germany], Aluminum isopropoxide (Al(O-i-Pr)3) [98%, LOBA Chemie, India], 2-Propanol [99.5%, sd fine, India], Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2.6H2O) [≥ 97%, Merck India], Magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2·6H2O) [99%, Merck India], Zirconium oxychloride octahydrate (ZrOCl2.8H2O) [99%, LOBA Chemie, India], Ruthenium trichloride trihydrate [RuCl3·3H2O] (LOBA Chemie, India). Double purified Millipore water is used for preparation of the catalysts. 2.2 Preparation of silica doped mesoporous alumina (SDA) The SDA material is prepared by following the procedure as reported by Zhao et al. [32]. In this synthesis procedure, 18.0 g P123 is added to 108 mL ethanol and 18 mL hydrochloric acid (35%) mixture and stirred continuously until a clear homogeneous solution is formed. To this homogeneous solution, a mixture of 72 mL 2-propanol and 3.125 g TEOS is added drop wise with continuous stirring. Another part of 72 mL ethanol is used for quantitative transfer of TEOS in reaction mixture. Now the whole content is stirred for 1.0 h and then has been kept at room temperature for 12.0 h. After that 37.786 g of Al(O-i-Pr)3 is slowly added to this solution and vigorously stirred for 12.0 h and resulting gel is kept at room temperature for 24 h. After that the resulting gel is transferred in a static air oven and kept at 60 °C for 10 h and at 80 °C for another 12 h and subsequently calcined at 700 °C for 6 h with 1.0 °C/min temperature increment rate. The material obtained after calcinations is crushed in a mortar pestle and is stored in a vacuum desiccators. The prepared SDA material is denoted as SDA(x) [where x = Mole % of silica]. 2.3 Preparation of Co-Mg-Zr/SDA by wet impregnation method In this procedure, Co, Mg and Zr are impregnated on support material (SDA) by wet impregnation method. In this method required amount of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, ZrOCl2.8H2O [Co:Mg:Zr = 15:5.2:2.5 wt %] are dissolved in 50 mL ethanol with continuous stirring until a clear homogeneous solution is formed. After that required amount of SDA material is added to it and stirred continuously until ethanol gets evaporated, further 20 mL of ethanol is added to it and stirred continuously until it gets evaporated and this process is repeated for two times. After complete evaporation of ethanol, the solid material is dried at 80 °C for 15 h and subsequently calcined at 350 °C temperature for 6.0 h with 1 °C/min temperature incremental rate. The solid material is obtained after calcinations is crushed in mortar pestle and stored in vacuum desiccator. 2.4 Deposition of Ru on Co-Mg-Zr/SDA material by deposition-precipitation method The ruthenium is deposited on Co-Mg-Zr/SDA material by precipitation method. In this procedure required quantity of RuCl3.3H2O [0.05 wt%] is dissolve in 500 mL deionized water with continuously stirring and simultaneously solution temperature is increased up to 70 °C with maintaining the pH of the solution at 7.5 by adding (N/20) NaHCO3 solution. Required quantity of Co-Mg-Zr/SDA material is added to this solution and stirred continuously for 2.0 h at 70 °C and subsequently solid mass is separated by filtration using Whatmann No. 42 filter paper and washed thoroughly by 100 mL deionized water. The solid mass, obtained after filtration and subsequent washing, is dried at 80 °C for 12 h and then calcined at 350 °C for 6 h in a muffle furnace with 1 °C/min temperature increment rate. After calcinations the prepared catalyst is stored in a vacuum desiccator and denoted as Ru/Co-Mg-Zr/SDA(x) [Where x = mole% of silica] 2.5 Characterization of catalyst The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of the catalysts is measured by using BET Surface Area analyzer (Model: TriStar, Make: Micromeritics, USA) instrument at liquid N2 temperature. The surface areas and pore size distributions of the catalysts are calculated from N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm by using Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation and BJH method. The X-ray diffraction pattern has been carried out by using a Powder X-Ray Diffractometer diffractometer (Model: D-8 Advance, Make: Bruker AXS, Germany) operated at a 40 kV voltage and 40 mA current and calibrated with a standard silicon sample, using Ni-fltered Cu Kα (λ = 0.15406 nm) radiation. The high resolution transmission electron microscopy with elemental mapping is done by using a JEOL JEM 2100 microscope, operated at 200 kV acceleration voltages using a lacy carbon coated Cu-grid of 300 mesh size. The Temperature Programmed Reduction (TPR) and Temperature Programmed Desorption (TPD) profiles of the catalysts are measured by using the Chemisorb 2720 (Make: Micrometrics, USA) instrument equipped with a TCD detector. The H2-TPR profiles are obtained by flowing 10% H2 in Ar (balance) with a flow rate of 20 mL min−1 and the temperature is increased from ambient to 1000 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1. The NH3-TPD profile of the catalysts is obtained by adsorbing 0.4% NH3 in He (balance) on reduced catalyst surface at room temperature and then the adsorbed gas is desorbed in He flow at a flow rate of 20 mL min−1 and the temperature is increased from ambient to 1000 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1. 2.6 Fischer Tropsch (FT) synthesis The catalytic performance of the prepared catalyst towards Fischer-Tropsch reaction is carried out on a continuous flow fixed bed reactor system (Internal diameter: 10 mm, Volume: 10 mL) equipped with CO & H2 mass flow controllers (Make: Brooks), back pressure regulator (Make: Tescom), gas-liquid separating system, catalyst bed temperature sensor and digital pressure-temperature gauge. In this process 3 mL powdered catalyst is packed in fixed bed stainless steel reactor and leak test is performed in N2 pressure of 30 bar for 24 h. The reactor is then heated at 120 °C for 4 h in N2 flow for removal of surface adsorbed moisture. The catalyst is reduced at 380 °C for 15 h in H2 flow (Purity: 99.999%, GHSV: 400 h−1) at 2 bar pressure and subsequently the reactor is cooled down to 150 °C in H2 flow. FT Synthesis experiment is then carried out with the flow of synthesis gas composition (H2 = 28.63%, CO = 14.27%, CO2 = 9.25%, CH4 = 1%, N2 = 46.85%) equivalent to coal gasification product and consequent WGS reaction. The reactor pressure is raised up to the reaction pressure (30 bar) by using synthesis gas by regulating Back Pressure Regulator (BPR) and simultaneously catalyst bed temperature is raised up to 220 °C (@ 1 °C/min increment rate). The activity of the catalyst is evaluated with on-stream experiment for 300 h with feed gas flow rate @ GHSV  = 500 h−1. During this reaction, the product gas analysis is carried out at different time intervals by using online Gas Chromatograph (Make: Chemito, Model: GC 1000) equipped with TCD [Column: Molecular Sieve 5A] and FID [Column: Porapak Q]. The liquid hydrocarbon product obtained on completion of the experiment, is analyzed by Gas Chromatograph (Make: Thermo Fischer, Trace 1110) equipped with FID and TR-1 (Make: Thermo Fischer Scientific) capillary column (Length: 30 m, Diameter: 0.32 mm, Film Thickness: 0.25 μm). 3 Results and discussions 3.1 X-Ray diffraction pattern The X-ray diffraction pattern of the catalysts are represented in Fig. 1 which indicates that the cobalt is mainly present as Co3O4 species (2θ = 31.15°, 36.65, 44.61, 59.08, 64.93). Magnesium has not developed any independent phase signifying high dispersion of it in the catalyst [33]. The XRD pattern corroborates HRTEM results where no aggregated crystalline magnesia has been detected. The absence of magnesia phase in the catalysts may be due to the formation of mixed oxide phase of CoO–MgO where Mg+2 occupying the Co+2 site in the CoO lattice. Therefore magnesia and CoO–MgO solid solution gives reflections at near identical 2θ positions [34,35]. Beside the formation of CoO-MgO solid solution there is also the probability for formation of cobalt-aluminum mixed oxide with the different composition like Co3O4, CoAl2O4, Co2AlO4 and nonstoichiometric Co-Al oxides, which have very close lattice parameters so the lattice planes produces reflection at identical 2θ positions [36,37]. The XRD profile of the catalyst after reaction show very sharp XRD peak (2θ = 21.48° & 23.85°) which is due to the accumulation of long-chain saturated hydrocarbons (paraffin wax) on catalyst surface. The low intensity of XRD pattern revels that the formation of small nanocrystalline phase of Co3O4 and CoO–MgO phase which are highly dispersed on SDA Material [38]. This highly dispersed cobalt species produces higher catalytic activity towards FTS process. The small crystallites of active metal phase can anchor in the pores of mesoporous support and remain in highly dispersed state which reduces the sintering of active metal phase [39]. 3.2 N2 Adsorption-desorption isotherm and pore size distribution The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and pore size distribution of catalyst are presented in Figs. 2 and 3 . All samples show typical Type – IV(a) adsorption isotherms, suggesting the mesoporous nature of the catalysts. The irreversibility of capillary condensation between adsorption and desorption of N2 at liquid nitrogen temperature in the pores and aggregated intra-particle spaces of the catalysts produce this kind of isotherm pattern [40]. The results as listed in Table 1 , shows that after metals incorporations there is 40–45% decrease in surface area and 20–25% decrease in pore diameter of the catalysts. This phenomenon is due to the partial filling of pores of SDA material with metals oxide nanoclusters. The isotherms of the catalysts show H1 & H3 type hysteresis loops which indicate plate like nanoclusters forming slit like pores [41]. This experimental result is also supported by the HRTEM results in the present study. The pore size distributions of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 and it is observed that there is a broad range of pore size distribution for Al2O3, Ru/Co-Mg-Zr/SDA(5) and Ru/Co-Mg-Zr/SDA(10). These results can be attributed to disordered structure of mesoporous alumina and the irregular shapes of intra-crystallite voids which are randomly stacked. It is further to observe that SDA (7.5) and Ru/Co-Mg-Zr/SDA(7.5) catalysts show bi-modal pore distribution compared to poly-modal pore distribution of other catalysts. The bi-modal pore distribution of support material is observed due to phase separation in sol-gel reaction of TEOS and Al(O-i-Pr)3 in presence of surfactant [42]. The poly-modal pore distribution of the catalyst may be due to the combined effect of pore distribution of support material and inter-particles pores between metal nanoclusters. 3.3 High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) The HRTEM images of SDA(7.5) [A & A1], Co-Mg-Zr/SDA(7.5) [B & B1] and Ru/Co-Mg- Zr/SDA(7.5) [C & C1] are represented in Fig. 4 . The SDA(7.5) shows plate like crystallite which forms porous network of the support material. The cobalt nanocrystallites having average diameter in the range of 5–10 nm are distributed on the SDA (7.5) material [B & B1, C & C1]. The ruthenium content of the catalyst Ru/Co-Mg-Zr/SDA(7.5) [C & C1] is so less that neither it can give the distinguish particle distribution nor it forms Ru – Co mixed phase. The individual particle size distribution and elemental composition of Ru/Co-Mg-Zr/SDA(7.5) [C & C1] catalyst is given in STEM with elemental mapping and EDS spectrum (Supporting information Figs. S1, S2). The STEM image shows almost homogeneous distribution of the metallic element but in case of Co some aggregated Co3O4 nanoclusters are formed (Fig. S1). Ethanol being an organic solvent facilitates better metal dispersion during metal [Co, Mg, Zr] impregnation [39] because the lower surface tension of ethanol effectively penetrates the porous network of the SDA material. It is also observed that after metal incorporation, the plate like structure of SDA material remains unchanged which supports N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm results. 3.4 H2-Temperature programmed reduction H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . All catalysts display a sharp reduction peak in the temperature range of 220–370 °C. The individual peak of each catalyst indicates the formation of metallic cobalt nanoclusters via two step reduction of Co3O4 nanocrystallite [Co3O4 + H2 = 3CoO + H2O and CoO + H2 = Co + H2O] with intermediate formation of CoO species [43,44]. The second reduction peak in the 500–600 °C temperature range indicates well dispersed Co3+ ion on the surface of SDA material [45]. It is well known fact that the reduction of cobalt species dependent on the presence of neighboring cation particularly Mg and Al because cobalt form spinel like structure with Mg and Al [46]. The small quantity of Mg suppresses the interaction between cobalt and alumina, therefore proportion of Co3O4 reduction is improved [47] [Supporting Information Table S3]. In case of Ru/Co-Zr/SDA(7.5) catalyst, the reduction temperature corresponding to Co3O4 shows higher temperature compared to other catalyst, this result also suggests that the small amount of Mg reduces the interaction between cobalt oxide and SDA support material [34]. From H2-TPR profile (Fig. 5) it is observed that the reduction temperature of Ru promoted catalyst is reduced substantially and intensity of reduction peaks are also increased. The shifting of reduction peaks of Ru promoted catalyst towards lower temperature region may be due to the hydrogen spillover effect [48–50]. The presence of Ru also facilitates the reduction of cobalt species by dissociating H2 molecule to give active hydrogen atom. This decrease in reduction temperature by addition of Ru may be closely related to the improved catalytic performance of Ru deposited catalyst. 3.5 NH3-Temperature programmed desorption The NH3-TPD profiles of the catalysts are produced in Fig. 6 . The silica doping into the alumina matrix increases the Bronsted acidity of the SDA material. Two close peaks at around 500 °C and 570 °C are observed in the catalysts which may be due to the strong acid site of the catalysts. The acidic site of the catalyst reduces the long chain hydrocarbon accumulation by cracking/isomerization process which prolongs the life of catalyst during FTS reaction. The total acidity of the catalyst is a synergistic effect of the promoters namely Ru, Mg and Zr in combination with active metal component Co where Mg occupies the Co site by the formation of CoO-MgO mixed oxide. This is evident as the addition of MgO on Ru/Co-Zr/SDA(7.5) has not decreased the acidity of the Ru/Co-Mg-Zr/SDA(7.5) catalyst (Table 2 ). Influence of zirconia is more evident than magnesia towards influencing the overall acidity of the catalyst. 3.6 Fischer-Tropsch synthesis The catalytic performance of a series of cobalt based catalysts are investigated for LTFT synthesis at 30 bar pressure and 220 °C temperature using equivalent syngas composition obtained from air blown gasification of coal with subsequent WGS reaction to have the H2/CO ratio ∼2.0. The catalytic activities of the catalysts are summarized in Table 3 and it is also observed that Ru promoted catalysts show much higher CO conversion efficiency and selectivity towards middle distillate. Among these catalysts, Ru/Co-Mg-Zr/SDA(7.5) catalyst shows 94.2% CO and 62.8% H2 conversion. This improved CO conversion activity is due to the increased reducibility of the cobalt phase by hydrogen spillover effect because Ru increases reducibility by lowering the temperature compared to cobalt so Ru acts as a reduction nuclei which facilitate hydrogen spillover effect [51–53]. Ru not only acts as a reduction promoter but also structural promoter by increasing number of effective active Co sites which promote the CO adsorption to facilitate the CO conversion [54,55]. The intimate contact of Ru on Co rather than support material enhances the promotional activity of Ru. The deposition–precipitation method for Ru incorporation on Co-Mg-Zr/SDA material promotes close contact of Ru on Co phase rather than SDA support material so Ru improves the activity of Co site for FT synthesis. The presence of Ru also improves CO dissociation as well as hydrogenation of adsorbed CO on catalyst surface. The incorporation of Zr and Mg also promotes the catalytic activity of cobalt phase where Zr promotes the reduction of cobalt oxide phase by suppressing the formation of cobalt aluminate and cobalt silicate phase [56]. It is reported by several researcher that ZrOCl2, used as a Zr precursor for catalyst preparation produces ZrOxCly intermediate which act as a mobile intermediate during calcinations step and this mobile intermediate induces higher metal dispersion with smaller crystallite sizes [31,57,58]. Magnesium also promotes catalyst life by inhibiting deposition of coke on catalyst surface. In the present study (Table S3, Supporting Information), it is observed that Zr addition induces more H2 consumption [Ru/Co-Zr/SDA(7.5)] compared to Mg addition [Ru/Co-Mg/SDA(7.5)], this experimental observation is due to the formation of certain proportion of CoO-MgO phase which reduces the carbon deposition on catalyst surface [31]. The combined effect of Ru, Zr and Mg improved CO dissociation, hydrogenation, cobalt oxide reduction and also reduces carbon deposition on catalyst surface. From experimental observation (Table 3) the selectivity of C2-C5 and C6-C18 is higher in case of Ru/Co-Mg/SDA(7.5), Ru/Co-Zr/SDA(7.5) and Ru/Co-Mg-Zr/SDA(7.5) catalyst compared to other catalysts. This observation can be ascribed with the acidity of the catalyst surface which results cracking/isomerization of long chain hydrocarbons inducing higher selectivity of C2-C18 hydrocarbon. The extent of hydrocracking reaction largely depends on the distance between acidic site and Co over the corresponding catalyst. The mesopores with narrow layered structure of the catalyst reduces the distance between acidic sites and Co of the corresponding catalyst which favors H2 spillover from Co to acidic site [51]. The enhanced H2 spillover effect favors hydrocracking reaction which produces less olefin. From Table 3 it is observed that the olefin/paraffin ratio is lower in case of SDA(7.5) supported metal catalyst compared to SDA(5) and SDA(10) supported metal catalyst. The lower olefin/paraffin ratio may be due to the narrow layerd structure of SDA(7.5) support material. The mesoporosity of SDA material not only increases the higher metal dispersion but also facilitates the removal of long chain hydrocarbon which maintains the clean catalytically active surface for long term activity during FTS reaction. The higher dispersion of cobalt species increases the degree of reduction of cobalt oxide which minimizes the methane formation reaction. This improved catalyst activity facilitating chain growth and release from the active site, keeps the active site ready for further catalytic activity and also minimize carbon deposition which produces clean surface to re-adsorb olefins [59]. The pore encapsulation of SDA material by metal oxide nanoclusters reduces the pore diameter of the catalysts and consequently narrowing of pore facilitates re-adsorption of olefins which induces chain growth during FT synthesis [60–63]. The stable activity of the catalysts (300 h) is due to effective removal of hydrocarbons by chain growth termination and resistance to coke formation on the catalyst surface. The Ru/Co-Mg- Zr/SDA(7.5) catalyst shows ∼94% CO conversion and 85% middle distillate selectivity and each catalyst also shows some proportion of CO2 hydrogenation reaction which reduces CO2 percentage in exhaust gas. This observation supports previous studies by several researchers that Co, Mg and Zr also have CO2 hydrogenation activity (Table 4 ) [64–66]. The LTFT synthesis with higher middle distillate selectivity is a preferred phenomenon for FTS research because in case of LTFT wax selectivity is higher however present Ru/Co-Mg-Zr/SDA catalyst shows higher selectivity towards middle distillate. The Ru un-promoted catalyst gives higher C19+ and CH4 selectivity compared to Ru-promoted catalyst. The higher C19+ selectivity is due to the lower acidity of Ru un-promoted catalyst which reduces cracking of higher hydrocarbon compared to Ru promoted catalyst. The wax formation on catalyst bed facilitates the coke formation, which blocks the catalytically active site and regulates the CH4 formation as well as decrease CO conversion [67]. The FT product distribution is obtained from Anderson-Schulz–Flory (ASF) plot (Fig. 7 ) which is plotted against log (Wn/n) vs n [where Wn = Mass % of the component with carbon number n] and the chain growth probability 'α' is obtained from the slope of the graph from the Eq. (1) (1) l o g W n n = n l o g α + l o g ( 1 - α ) 2 α Experimental results (Table 3) show that Ru/Co-Mg-Zr/Al2O3 and Ru/Co-Mg-Zr/SDA(5) show almost similar CO conversion as well as C19+ and CH4 selectivity. From ASF distribution plot (Fig. 7), it is observed that the hydrocarbon product does not follow typical ASF distribution where the hydrocarbon product fraction decreases linearly with increasing carbon number. In the present work there is a decrease of hydrocarbon mole fraction in between C3-C5 and then increases from C6 to C9 after that it decreases (Fig. 8 ). In the present study, the chain growth probability (α) of the catalysts varies in the range of 0.80 to 0.85 (Table 3). Cumulative frequency of each Cn has been plotted (Fig. 9 ) for the catalysts to understand the product distribution with respect to the Cn. Ru, Zr and SDA containing catalysts show a sharp inflection at C6 and sharp increase of selectivity in C6–C19 range. This cumulative frequency plot for product distribution of the present catalysts indicates towards a combined role of Ru, Zr and SDA for higher middle distillate selectivity during the FTS process. 4 Conclusion The mesoporous SDA material was successfully synthesized and effectively used as a support material for development of highly active and durable cobalt based catalyst for selective middle distillate synthesis by using equivalent feed gas composition obtained from air blown gasification of coal. Beside this the catalysts also show some extent of CO2 hydrogenation activity which reduces CO2 percentage in exhaust gas. From characterization and experimental results it is observed that narrow pore size distribution, acidic site and dispersion of active metal site are responsible for highest CO conversion and middle distillate selectivity. It is also observed that the combined effect of Ru, Zr, Mg and Si is effective for selective middle distillate synthesis via LTFT process. Acknowledgements S. coredata.dc:description: A series of silica doped alumina (SDA) [Si-Al2O3] having high surface area and narrow pore size distribution are synthesized with varying amount of silica and used as a support material to facilitate incorporation of Co, Mg and Zr into it. These supported Co-Mg-Zr/SDA materials are used as catalysts for selective synthesis of middle distillate through Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) reaction. Trace quantity (∼0.05 wt %) of ruthenium (Ru) has also been used as a promoter for Co -Mg-Zr/SDA catalyst to improve the reducibility, selectivity towards middle distillate and increasing the catalyst life. The detail characterizations of catalysts indicate that Ru promotion and narrow pore size distribution facilitate CO conversion and middle distillate selectivity. Synthetic syngas of composition (H2 = 28.63%, CO = 14.27%, CO2 = 9.25%, CH4 = 1.0%, and N2 = 46.85%), which may be obtained after coal gasification and H2 enrichment process by water gas shift (WGS) reaction has been used as a reactant for middle distillate synthesis. The role of Ru and silica proportion on Co-Mg-Zr/SDA is investigated through Low Temperature Fischer-Tropsch (LTFT) synthesis at 220 °C temperature and 30 bar pressure. The surface acidity of the Ru/Co-Mg-Zr/SDA catalyst plays an important role for middle distillate selectivity and CO conversion. To determine the durability of catalysts, 300 h continuous experimental run has been conducted at Gas Hourly Space Velocity (GHSV) of 500 h−1. Among the catalysts in the present study, Ru/Co-Mg-Zr/SDA(7.5) catalyst shows highest CO conversion (94.2%) with 85% selectivity of C6-C19 hydrocarbon.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of middle distillate through low temperature Fischer-Tropsch (LTFT) reaction over mesoporous SDA supported cobalt catalysts using syngas equivalent to coal gasification
